title: The Talons of Weng-Chiang
dialogue_triumphs: The Doctor: 'I'm trying to teach you'
goofs: Modern power-points covered with masking tape visible on the walls of Litefoot's lab
1970s newspaper with Denis Healey headline visible in Litefoot's laundry basket in episode three
Boom-mike shadow visible on the curtains near the stage in the final fight

continuity_notes.name: Leela
continuity_notes.description: The Doctor's companion, known for her primitive warrior skills
continuity_notes.current_status: Kills a Tong agent with a janis thorn and blowpipe, to the Doctor's discomfort

continuity_notes.name: The Doctor
continuity_notes.description: Time Lord protagonist, currently in his fourth incarnation
continuity_notes.current_status: Investigating mysterious events in Victorian London

roots: The Phantom Raspberry Blower of Old London Town
The Man with the Golden Gun
The Condition of the Working Class in England

locations.name: Victorian London
locations.description: The primary setting of the story, between 1889 and 1901
locations.current_status: Plagued by mysterious murders and strange occurrences

future_history: In the 51st century, Magnus Greel was the infamous Minister of Justice, known as 'the butcher of Brisbane'. The Peking Homunculus was created around the year 5000 for the Commissioner of the Icelandic Alliance's children. It contained a pig's cerebral cortex, which nearly caused World War Six.
untold_adventures: The Doctor was with the Filipino army at the final advance on Reykjavik in the 51st century
The Doctor once fished the river Fleet and caught a salmon which he shared with the Venerable Bede
qv: Dating the Segments of Time, 'The Ark'
additional_notes: The story features another classic Robert Holmes double act, the theatrical Henry Jago and Professor Litefoot, although they don't actually meet until episode five.
bottom_line: One of the great moments of Doctor Who's history – an effortless conquering of the pseudo-historical genre with a peerless script.
